newacro.long: Preparing Programming Assignments for Submission System

preamble.newacro: A system designed to help prepare programming assignments for submission. The assignment specifications (such as required files) are provided by lecturers in a remote XML file. This system doesn’t submit your work.
preamble.newterm: An application with a graphical user interface that uses the library to help prepare project code for submission.

A file that’s required by the assignment specifications. The file name (case-sensitive) must match the name identified in the specification. Required files are listed first in the PDF in the order identified by the assignment specifications.

A supplementary file that’s not required by the assignment specification but forms part of your project code and should be included in the PDF submission. Additional files will be listed after any required files in the PDF.
A file provided by your lecturer as part of the assignment specifications that your project code must read. Resource files should not be edited or renamed by you. They are not listed in the PDF.
A file that should be created by your project code. If successfully created, result files will be included in the PDF.

node.title: Introduction
node.p: is a simple IDE with the library integrated into it. It’s designed for use in practical exams or tests conducted in the lab where a standard IDE would provide too much help. It therefore has a very basic interface and only works with projects that have been setup for use with .

p.strong: is not a general purpose IDE.

node.p: shares the same settings file as . By default, this is a file called .progassignsys.prop saved in your home directory.

node.title: Select a Project

image.alt: Image of select a project dialog.

node.p: When you launch you need to select a project, which must correspond to an assignment that has been setup to use .

li.p: If you haven’t started working on any code yet, choose and click on . You will then need to specify an empty folder to store your project files in. With most look and feels, the directory selection dialog box allows you to create a new folder, which you can then select. For example, shows the dialog with the Nimbus look and feel.

image.alt: Image of file chooser dialog.

li.p: Once you have selected the folder, you next need to select a course.
If you have already started work on a project with , choose and click on . You can then select the project file (which has the extension).

image.alt: Image of file chooser dialog.

li.p: If you have started work on a project using another editor and now want to work on it with , choose and click on . You then need to select the folder the project files are in ().

image.alt: Image of file chooser dialog.

li.p: Once you have selected the folder, you next need to select a course.

node.title: Select a Course
node.p: Once you have chosen your project folder, you then need to select the course. For example, in the course CMP-4008Y (Programming 1) has been selected. Click to continue.

image.alt: Image of select course dialog.

node.p: Next you need to select an assignment.

node.title: Select an Assignment
node.p: The assignment selector () has a drop-down widget where you can select the assignment. You also need to provide your Blackboard ID and student registration number. If you have already used on the same device, can fetch the information as it shares the same settings file as . As with other applications, you can’t proceed any further until you check the agreement box. It’s important that you check the PDF file created by correctly represents your work before you submit it.

image.alt: Image of select assignment dialog.

node.p: In , the assignment CMP-4008Y Coursework 1 - Film Information Database has been chosen. This assignment has three : Film.java, FilmDatabase.java and Main.java. If this is a new project, will automatically create them. If you are importing files that have been created in a different IDE, then will create any missing . The assignment data may provide a template for one or more . If so, the template will be used when creating the file. (For example, your task may be to fix bugs and complete code stubs.)
Once found or created, all the will then be opened in read/write mode. Any can be imported or created using the menu.

If the assignment comes with any that your project code needs to read, then will automatically fetch those files and open them in read-only mode. For example, the CMP-4008Y assignment comes with a data file films.txt so will fetch this file and open it in read-only mode.
If the project code must create any then will search for them and, if found, open them in read-only mode.

Any local resource or result files viewable in are only input/output by the quick test build function (). When you use the full function (), fresh copies of any will be fetched from their remote location. The included in the PDF will be those created by that build not the local copies in your project folder.

node.title: Main Window
node.p: The main window consists of a navigation panel on the left, tabbed editor panes on the right, a toolbar above and tabbed message areas below. You can remove unwanted buttons on the toolbar using the Properties dialog to reduce clutter.

node.title: Navigation Panel
node.p: The navigation panel only shows those files associated with the project. Double-click on the file name to open the file or single-click to select the associated tab if the file is already open. A popup menu is available that provides some of the items from the menu. The [] folder indicates the main project directory.

node.title: Editor Panel
node.p: The editor panel displays each open file in a separate tab. You can reorder them by dragging and dropping the tabs. A file can be closed by clicking on the close button on the tab or using the menu item. A tab can be selected by clicking on the tab or by clicking on the associated file name in the navigation panel.
In , a is selected. There is an area to edit the (currently empty) file. Above that area is a horizontal bar that contains information about the file.

The area on the left of the information bar identifies the type of file. This includes whether the file is a , , or . In the case of , , there is also a drop-down list that identifies the file language (such as Java or C). This information is either obtained from the file extension or from the assignment data. You need to check that this information is correct as uses this information to determine the code listing syntax and also whether the file should be passed to the compiler.
The area on the right of the information bar shows the current cursor location. You can choose a more compact form in the Properties dialog.

image.alt: Image of editor panel showing a required file.

node.p: In , a is selected. The area on the left of the file information bar now shows . The file content can be viewed but can’t be edited.

image.alt: Image of editor panel showing a read-only resource file.

node.p: If the isn’t a text file then the content can’t be viewed and there is just a button on the right () that can be used to launch the appropriate application to view the file (if supported).

image.alt: Image of editor panel showing a read-only binary resource file.

node.p: In , a is selected. This is a file that has been created by your project code in a local build within your project folder. The equivalent file created with the full function () will be added to the PDF file and should be the same as this local copy. However, it’s important that you check the PDF file to ensure that it is correct.

image.alt: Image of editor panel showing a read-only result file.

node.p: In this case, the left hand area of the horizontal bar shows . As with , a may be a binary file, in which case the content will again not be shown and there will be a button to launch the appropriate application to view it (if supported).

image.alt: Image of editor panel showing a binary read-only result file.

node.p: If you use the text search function a search shortcut widget is displayed in the middle of the file information bar (). You can use the up and down arrow buttons to find the next or previous instance or the button to reopen the find dialog (if it has been dismissed). There is also a close button to hide the search widget.

image.alt: Image of application showing search widget.

node.title: The Toolbar
node.p: The toolbar is situated above the navigator and editor panes and below the menu bar. It contains buttons for quick access to some common menu items. If the toolbar is too wide for the window, widgets will appear to scroll along it. You can use the dialog to hide unwanted buttons to reduce clutter or to choose smaller icons.

node.title: The Status Bar
node.p: The status bar is situated at the bottom of the window. On the left are buttons to clear the content of the currently selected message tab or to copy all the text (or just the selected text, if any applicable) of the currently selected message tab to the clipboard.
The right hand side of the status bar shows the course code and assignment title.

When building code (either with or ) a progress bar becomes visible in the middle of the status bar, with an abort button and a timer. If a sub-process is running (such as the compiler or the test run of the application), the abort button will stop the sub-process but the main process will continue (so the PDF may still be completed with a full build). Clicking the abort button a second time will stop the main process.
The progress bar switches to indeterminate when performing the test as there is no way of determining how long an arbitrary application will run.

node.title: The Menu Bar
node.p: The menu bar is situated at the top of the window, below the title bar.

node.title: The File Menu
node.p: The menu provides the following functions:

dl.dd: Saves the file showing in the currently selected tab. (Does nothing for read-only files.) Note that there is no Save as option as the file names are determined when they are created.
Saves all modified open files. Both the and menu items automatically save all modified files.

Runs a test build according to the build information given in the assignment data. By default, this will compile the code (if the language is compilable) and then run it. This test build is a cut-down version of the way usually works. It’s designed for quick testing, so it doesn’t fetch fresh copies of any and uses the project folder as the current working directory. Any messages from the build process can be found in the message tabs at the bottom of the main window.

Sends the project information to the backend, in the same way as other applications. This will copy your project files to temporary working directory and fetch fresh copies of any . If successful, a PDF is created, which you can save and view. Make sure you check the PDF before you submit it. If any problems show up in the PDF, you will need to address them and rerun .
Once you have run (using the previous menu item) and a PDF file has been successfully created, you can view it with this menu item.

node.title: Project Files
node.p: The project files must all be located within the project directory structure. These consist of source code files that must be processed by , files that needs to fetch, and files that are created by your project code.

Each project has an associated file called code-label, where code is the course code and label is the assignment label. This file contains all the information that needs to be sent to the backend (Blackboard ID, registration number, project files, agreement checkbox has been selected, etc). This file is automatically saved whenever this information changes (for example, if a new is created or imported).

When you use the quick test build function () the local copy in your project folder will be used. When you use the full function (), a fresh copy will be fetched from the remote location and put in working directory.

should be created by your project code. When you use the quick test build function () and the file or files are successfully created and can be found in the project folder, then they will be added to the navigation tree. They can’t be edited, renamed, moved or deleted within . You can view them to ensure that they have been created correctly. However, when you use the full function () fresh copies will be created in working directory and it will be those copies that are added to your PDF, not the local copies in your project folder.

If you want to rename, move or delete the file, use the , or menu item, respectively. Note that you can’t move the file outside of the project tree. (More complex file operations will have to be done using your device’s standard filing system tools.) If you no longer want the file included in the project but don’t want to delete it, use the menu item. To include an existing file into your project file list, use the menu item.

node.title: Project Details
node.p: The dialog box () can be opened with the menu item. It will also be opened if you try to run when your student details are missing.

image.alt: Image of project details dialog.

node.p: This dialog lists the course code, assignment title and due date. These elements can’t be changed. You can change your Blackboard ID and registration number if you made a mistake when you entered them in the assignment selector.

If you are working on a group project, you can also add the other members of your project team. To add a new row, use the or buttons. You can delete the selected row with the provided there is more than one row in the table.

node.title: Moving a File
node.p: The dialog is displayed when you use the menu item. The dialog shows a trimmed down version of the project directory structure in the navigator panel that only shows folders. Select the destination folder.

image.alt: Image of file move to dialog.

node.p: If you use your operating system’s standard file moving tool, you will have to remove the file from the project listing (). Note that project files can’t be located outside of the project directory structure.

node.title: Locating Text or a Line
node.p: There are two main ways of finding a location within the currently selected editor panel: using the text search function or using the line search function.

node.title: Search (and Replace)
node.p: The dialog (without replace) can be opened with the menu item or using the button in the file information bar at the top of the currently selected file editor panel.

image.alt: Image of find (no replace) dialog.

node.p: Use the button to find the first instance. Then use the or to find the next or previous instance.
If you want to search with a regular expression, make sure that the checkbox is selected.
If you want to replace text, use the menu item. This will open the dialog with the replace widgets visible. If the dialog is already visible, it will switch to find and replace mode.

image.alt: Image of find and replace dialog.

node.p: If you have regular expressions enabled, you can use n to reference a group. For example, shows the regular expression search term Hello ([A-Za-z]+) and the replacement text uses 1 to reference the group: Goodbye 1.

image.alt: Image of find and replace dialog showing regular expression back-reference.

node.title: Go To Line
node.p:
The dialog can be opened with the
menu item. Set the required line number and click on . This will place the cursor at the start of the given line number in the currently selected editor panel. Note that the cursor isn’t visible in read-only editor panels but the location will be scrolled to if necessary.

image.alt: Image of go to line dialog.

node.p: If you specify a line number that’s greater than the total number of lines in the file, the last line will be the target location.

If the compiler flags an error or warning formatted in the form filename:line or filename:line:column then this text will be turned into a hyperlink which can also take you to the corresponding location ().

image.alt: Image of hyperlink in compiler warning message.

node.title: Properties
node.p: The dialog can be opened with the menu item. There are three tabbed panes:

dl.dd:
This tab is split into two areas: the cursor location settings and the font.
The cursor location format (which is shown on the right of the information bar at the top of each editor panel) can be adjusted. You can choose whether this information should include the line number, the column number or the position from the start of the file. You can also choose whether to have long textual labels (line, column, position) or abbreviations (Ln, Cn, Pn) or no textual labels (just comma-separated numeric values).
The font selector allows you to specify the font used in the editor panels. A monospaced font is best for source code, so the checkbox can be used to filter the font list so that it only shows monospaced fonts. Unselect this checkbox if you want a list of all available fonts. The font size is also used for the message areas. The font family is used for verbatim content (such as compiler messages).
The Tab

This tab allows you to set the default font used in the online manual (this document).
The Tab

This tab allows you to change the look and feel, set the font size used in general widgets, and customize the toolbar.
If you change the look and feel, some of the panels and dialog boxes may become too small or too large. You may need to quit and restart if this causes a problem.
If you change the widget font size (which governs the size of text in menus, buttons etc) then you will need to quit and restart for the new setting to be implemented. Similarly if you change the size of the toolbar button icons.
You can hide unwanted toolbar buttons by deselecting the checkbox next to the associated icon. This setting will take effect when you click on the button. Likewise you can hide any of the three separators.
